This is supporting teachers.

As Duke TeachHouse's first Innovation Fellow, I've become convinced quality education stems from a passionate educator, equipped with the tools to hone their practice.
  • Funded by:
  • Fidelity Investments
  • Duke Social Science Research Institute
  • Duke Program in Education
  • Example projects:
  • Virtual reality for cross-cultural understanding
  • Film-making for life storytelling
  • Learning weather through green screens
  • Making zombie films for learning videography

Even as the U.S. faces a shortage of qualified teachers, 30% of educators leave the classroom within five years.1 The dominant driver of this exodus is a lack of support within a teacher's classroom and school.2

TeachHouse aims to create this support for teachers by bringing them together into a common home.

One of the most critical areas in which teachers need support is the development of technology-enhanced instruction.

To create this support, I have integrated several theories of teacher education. The result is a framework that sees technology as a tool, teaching as a design science, and community as professional development.
Technology as a tool

Educational technology is useful to the extent that it fosters learning beyond what was previously possible. It is a means, not an end. With this principle in mind, I aim to help teachers use technology not to reproduce traditional schooling, but to promote student-centered practices. As a guide in the development of these technologies, I adapt the SAMR model popularized by Dr. Ruben Puentedura.

Substitution

Technologies that substitute allow a teacher to achieve the same instructional goals in a very similar way. For example, I may suggest that a teacher use free online textbooks as opposed to those in print.

Augmentation

Technologies that augment promote the same instructional goals in a new way, often helping us achieve more than before. For example, I have helped teachers use virtual reality alongside textbook passages—enabling greater reading comprehension.

Modification

Technologies that modify can improve the instructional goals themselves, perhaps enabling a shift from rote learning to the construction of knowledge. I have helped teachers use iPads to enable students to tell their life stories in the form of a "hero's journey"—helping students construct the term's relevance to their lives.

Redefinition

Technologies that redefine throw out old instructional goals and shift the role of teachers. I have worked on tools that enable teachers to take on the role of a knowledge maker using their classroom as a research site.

Teaching as a Design Science

Teaching as a design science (TDS), proposed by Laurillard (2012), frames teachers as engineers. Like engineers, teachers must design an intervention for their classroom that navigates its constraints—whether district policy or school culture. Crucially, these "pedagogical designs" can be scaled as other teachers adapt them to their own context. At TeachHouse, I use TDS to frame our development of technology-enhanced experiences: we first brainstorm barriers to implementation, and then ideate pathways to overcome them.

References:

  • Laurillard, D. (2012). Teaching as a Design Science: Building Pedagogical Patterns for Learning and Technology. New York, NY: Routledge.
  • Ling Koh, J. H., Chai, C. S., & Tay, L. Y. (2014). TPACK-in-Action: Unpacking the contextual influences of teachers’ construction of technological pedagogical content knowledge (TPACK). Computers & Education, 78, 20–29.
Community as Professional Development

Collaborative teacher teams have greater capacity to design new learning experiences that address the unique needs of their classrooms. Collaboration itself also increases the likelihood that teachers will choose to innovate in their instruction. Taking these principles and expanding upon them, the Innovation Lab at TeachHouse is intentionally situated in the house's living room. An open space for technology design, with a community at its heart, it enables more effective development processes.

References:

  • Vescio, V., Ross, D., & Adams, A. (2008). A Review of Research on the Impact of Professional Learning Communities on Teaching Practice and Student Learning. Teaching and Teacher Education: An International Journal of Research and Studies, 24(1), 80–91.
  • Ertmer, P. A., & Ottenbreit-Leftwich, A. T. (2010). Teacher Technology Change: How Knowledge, Confidence, Beliefs, and Culture Intersect. Journal of Research on Technology in Education, 42(3), 255–284.
  • Mueller, J., Wood, E., Willoughby, T., Ross, C., & Specht, J. (2008). Identifying discriminating variables between teachers who fully integrate computers and teachers with limited integration. Computers & Education, 51(4), 1523–1537.
